question.title: No suitable driver found when making SQL connection to MS Access Database in java

node.contents: Use `Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver");` before `con = DriverManager.getConnection(...)` .

astNode.text: Use `Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver");` before `con = DriverManager.getConnection(...)` .

node.contents: I have a Jbutton (GetDataFromDB) in a simple java application that is suppose to load the data from the database depicted in the path in the code below into a Jtable in the application.

astNode.text: I have a Jbutton (GetDataFromDB) in a simple java application that is suppose to load the data from the database depicted in the path in the code below into a Jtable in the application.

node.contents: Edited answer into code:

astNode.text: Edited answer into code:

elements.contents: private void GetDataFromDBActionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent evt) { Connection con; ResultSet rs = null; Statement stmt; try { Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver"); con = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:odbc:Driver={MS Access Driver (*.mdb, *.accdb)};Dbq=C:\\Users\\Bruger\\Documents\\Database11.accdb"); stmt = con.createStatement(); String query = null; query = "select * from cost"; rs = stmt.executeQuery(query); i = 0; while (rs.next()){ i = i + 1; jTable.getModel().setValueAt(rs.getString(1), i, 1); jTable.getModel().setValueAt(rs.getString(2), i, 2); } rs.close(); stmt.close(); con.close(); } catch(Exception err){ System.out.println(err.getMessage()); } }

units.rawText: private void GetDataFromDBActionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent evt) { Connection con; ResultSet rs = null; Statement stmt; try { Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver"); con = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:odbc:Driver={MS Access Driver (*.mdb, *.accdb)};Dbq=C:\\Users\\Bruger\\Documents\\Database11.accdb"); stmt = con.createStatement(); String query = null; query = "select * from cost"; rs = stmt.executeQuery(query); i = 0; while (rs.next()){ i = i + 1; jTable.getModel().setValueAt(rs.getString(1), i, 1); jTable.getModel().setValueAt(rs.getString(2), i, 2); } rs.close(); stmt.close(); con.close(); } catch(Exception err){ System.out.println(err.getMessage()); } }

node.contents: It's also worth mentioning you don't need to do this every time you get a connection, just once to make sure the class is loaded.

node.contents: There are a lot of stackoverflow questions relating to this, but the reason for it is below:

astNode.text: There are a lot of stackoverflow questions relating to this, but the reason for it is below:

node.contents: Source - From The Java Tutorial:

astNode.text: Source - From The Java Tutorial:

node.contents: In previous versions of JDBC, to obtain a connection, you first had to initialize your JDBC driver by calling the method Class.forName. This methods required an object of type java.sql.Driver. Each JDBC driver contains one or more classes that implements the interface java.sql.Driver. ... Any JDBC 4.0 drivers that are found in your class path are automatically loaded. (However, you must manually load any drivers prior to JDBC 4.0 with the method Class.forName.)

astNode.text: In previous versions of JDBC, to obtain a connection, you first had to initialize your JDBC driver by calling the method Class.forName. This methods required an object of type java.sql.Driver. Each JDBC driver contains one or more classes that implements the interface java.sql.Driver. ... Any JDBC 4.0 drivers that are found in your class path are automatically loaded. (However, you must manually load any drivers prior to JDBC 4.0 with the method Class.forName.)

node.contents: On a related and very important note.

astNode.text: On a related and very important note.

node.contents: I would also recommend looking up how to handle connections. External Resources like database connections and cursors are easy to leak if you are not familiar with them. Look up 'try finally blocks', or more recently in java 7+ 'try-with-resources'.

astNode.text: I would also recommend looking up how to handle connections. External Resources like database connections and cursors are easy to leak if you are not familiar with them. Look up 'try finally blocks', or more recently in java 7+ 'try-with-resources'.
